text: Can you say a little bit about
the social structure in the villages
and how that's been changed by
the success of the dairy cooperative movement?
Let me tell you, earlier
when Amul started,
mostly the farmers who had cows and buffalo,
were landowners,
Patidars - we call them Patels.
So they became the members.

But once they became members,
they got prosperous.
They educated their children.
You see, you go to USA, you go to Europe.

Most of the - you ask any 
Gujarati lady, old lady:

"What were you doing during
your childhood and younger days?"

She'll say, "I was pouring milk
in the village co-operatives."

So what happened, is that 
after getting education,
after getting prosperity, they went out.

But in the same way, 
new people entered.
Today you see that 70%

of members of our cooperative society
are landless and marginal farmers.
So it is like a hospital.
The livelihood patient enters the hospital.

You get well, you go out and 
other people enter.
So it is a continuous process.

One thing more - one advantage of 
the Amul model, Indian cooperative structure

vis-à-vis other dairy structures in the 
world is that one difference is there.

A farmer in India who's pouring
milk with the village society

gets 80% of what the consumer
pays in a city like Bombay or Delhi.

If you buy one liter of milk, if you pay
₹100, ₹80 are going to the farmer,
even private also.

In most of the developed countries, 
Europe, USA, New Zealand, Australia,
farmers will get only one third.
